subanswer.text: Let's think step by step. Let's say you consume exactly 1 calorie every second since midnight (this is very unlikely but it makes calculations easier). Let's call that moment t. So after eating this bag of chips, you'd be consuming calories at a rate of 1cal/sec, which would be the same as consuming them continuously from time zero (i.e., midnight) until time t. Then you'd have a cumulative intake of (1cal/sec * t) + 714641

We've already consumed 1800 calories, or 450 grams of food. The remaining number of grams we can consume is 500 - 450 = 50. Let's call our consumption rate k calories per second. By the end of our chip-eating session, we would have consumed a total of (1cal/sec * t) + 714641 calories. Since all the chips were consumed at once, their calories were also consumed instantaneously. But during the rest of the day, we would consume at a constant rate of k calories per second. Using the conservation of energy principle, the total number of calories we consume should equal the total number of calories available. So, 1cal/sec * t + k * (24*60*60 - t) = 7146410 + 1800.
